Package tools.data.file

Class WritableFileTree

  • java.lang.Object
    • tools.data.file.FileTree
      • tools.data.file.WritableFileTree
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    DirFileTree
    public abstract class WritableFileTree
extends FileTree
    Abstract file tree for adding write options to a file tree.

      • delete

        public boolean delete​(java.lang.String path)
               throws java.io.IOException
        Deletes the file at the given path. If the file denotes a directory, then all children of that directory are deleted.
        Also returns true if the given file doesn't exist.
        Parameters:
        path - The path of the file to be deleted.
        Returns:
        true if the file was deleted successfully. false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • delete

        public boolean delete​(TreeFile file)
               throws java.io.IOException

        Also returns true if the given file doesn't exist.
        Parameters:
        file - The file to be deleted.
        Returns:
        true if the file was deleted successfully. false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException

      • deleteFile

        public boolean deleteFile​(java.lang.String path)
                   throws java.io.IOException,
                          java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Deletes the file at the given file. The file cannot be a directory.
        Also returns true if the given file doesn't exist.
        Parameters:
        path - The path of the file to be deleted.
        Returns:
        true if the file was deleted successfully. false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If some I/O error occured.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given file was a directory.

      • deleteFile

        public abstract boolean deleteFile​(TreeFile file)
                            throws java.io.IOException,
                                   java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Deletes the given file. The file cannot be a directory.
        Also returns true if the given file doesn't exist.
        Parameters:
        file - The file to be deleted.
        Returns:
        true if the file was deleted successfully. false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If some I/O error occured.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given file was a directory.

      • deleteDir

        public boolean deleteDir​(java.lang.String path,
                         boolean deleteChildren)
                  throws java.io.IOException,
                         java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Deletes the file at the given path. The file must be a directory. Only deletes all children if deleteChildren == true, if there are any.
        Also returns true if the given directory doesn't exist.
        Parameters:
        path - The path of the file to be deleted.
        deleteChildren - Whether to delete the children of the directory, if it has any.
        Returns:
        true if the file was deleted successfully. false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If some I/O error occured.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given file was a directory.

      • deleteDir

        public abstract boolean deleteDir​(TreeFile file,
                                  boolean deleteChildren)
                           throws java.io.IOException,
                                  java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Deletes the given file. The file must be a directory. Only deletes all children if deleteChildren == true, if there are any.
        Also returns true if the given directory doesn't exist.
        Parameters:
        file - The file to be deleted.
        deleteChildren - Whether to delete the children of the directory, if it has any.
        Returns:
        true if the file was deleted successfully. false otherwise.
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If some I/O error occured.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given file was a directory.
